reviewText:
Nice try ... but not finished.

Playing sims/strategy/rpg genre quite often my expectations of this game have been too high.

It has a nice setup how you interact with your crew, fulfill their demands, but dies under too many random factors. For example, the perfect bartender has as psych attribute quiet" and "shy". It is not funny and will lead unexperienced player straight to a loss.
The "morale" system is very raw. People will get happy when you built many small rooms filled with monitor/plants. That means long hallways and big rooms are game breaking. You will lose every time cause of low morale. A drawback of many small rooms is the micromanagement in case of emergencies.


I do love their humor ... A chicken alien beat up a human who was eating because he thought the chicken legs have been from his race/planet.


Conclusio ...
Play Dwarf Fortress ....  It free but not that fancy and includes all the things Double Fine wanted to realize but didn't finish."

reviewText:
This is not Early Access any more, it's more like Early Abandonment.
At the Time of WritingGame: Spacebase DF-9
Price: $21.99*
Genre: building/simulation
Time Played: 25 hours
Personal Enjoyment Rating: ☺☻☻☻☻

Links I Found Helpful**
A YouTube gameplay look by Whole Brain Gaming. This video gives you a good idea of what the game is actually like to play as the narrator explores it. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_2G33jDCyc0

A YouTube discussion by Total Biscuit. His discussion will not only tell you a bit about all the drama surrounding this game, but you’ll also see some of the gameplay. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gAd8Ls8Mwl4

GeneralFor what little it is now worth, I did enjoy playing the game and exploring the changes in each new Alpha update. This game had a lot of potential and was very exciting. With gorgeous artwork, a decent attempt at UI design, atmospheric music, and an absolutely delightful sense of humour, all of which contributed to an interesting universe of different species and way of life. But the fact remains that this game was abandoned, never finished properly, and at the time of writing can not be considered a complete game.

They did go in and include a tutorial for the game, and I was very impressed with the tutorial until it suddenly ended. Although it felt like it ended abruptly and too soon, I can see why they did limit the information provided. If they don’t leave you to figure out the other rooms and the way the spacebase generally functions then you would have played all there is to play of this game in the tutorial. Ultimately the tutorial just seems to highlight the lack of depth to the game.

Spacebase has a rocky history so far, and I feel I really must include a discussion of this so that you can make an informed decision. However, as you will see with the format of my reviews, there are plenty of sections which allow me to consider the game for itself regardless of the surrounding drama.

In the interests of full disclosure: I was an early access purchaser, and yeah, I did get burned with this game. My experience with Spacebase truly set my mind to never buy an early access game ever again, no matter how wonderful it looks and tempting it seems. Nothing is a sure bet, and I will only be spending my money on finished products from now on. I can accept that I took a risk by purchasing an EA game and that it did not pan out in this case, but the end result is still a bad experience with Spacebase and Double Fine by extension. Things did get very dramatic, but I don’t think the company did a very good job of handling things. I’m not going to go on about it, so suffice it to say that I’m not an admirer of Double Fine any more. If you want more information regarding the drama I refer to, please check out TotalBiscuit’s discussion on the subject.

GameplayThis is a base building game. You build a space station from basic building blocks (floors and walls) and zone different rooms. You fill those rooms with things like oxygen tanks, plants, beds, exercise equipment, tables, food, defence turrets, fire extinguishers, science labs, and matter converters. Mine asteroids to refine into matter, the basic building block/currency of the game in order to build everything else.

There isn’t exactly a tech tree to this game, and there aren’t any crafting recipes (although there is scientific research). It seems to be more about the simulation of how people interact with one another, but there are so many characters that join your base that it’s impossible to really follow many interactions in a very meaningful way. So I end up concentrating on building the base and trying to see just how big I can make it. Once you get a vast crew though, things start lagging up and the bugs start to get obvious. Ultimately you will find that there is an imposed limit on how big a base you can create and keep running not by design, but because (I'm afraid I must repeat) this game wasn't really completed.

I really desperately wish that there was a blueprint function (like in prison architect) so that one could plan their base out before starting construction.

ControlsAlthough you can use the mouse to do everything, there are thankfully plenty of hotkeys. Some of them aren’t as intuitive as I might like, but I got used to them over the course of many hours of play. I found the camera controls to be fairly good, with my most appreciated camera functionality being the ability to pan around. It’s also always a plus to have a simple pause/start button to hit, which is good old spacebar.

StorylineI can’t say there is much of a storyline. I think the original intention for the game was to immerse yourself in the lives of the different people on the base and sort of imagine your own story. However, there isn’t sufficient depth and breadth to the rest of the game to allow you to direct any sort of imaginary storyline. It was an interesting concept which didn’t really get developed or thought through well enough.

SoundI really like the sound in this game. The music is quite atmospheric (appropriate to the universe they created) and interesting to listen to. It may get repetitive after a while, but it is more like it fades into the background of your awareness rather than becoming irritating. Meanwhile, the sound effects are pretty much functional, nothing much to warrant remark.

GraphicsThe artwork in this game is really very good. It’s certainly got a specific style to it, however that style is stuck to throughout and that consistency helps to establish a weird and wonderful universe. I really only have good things to say about the graphics, it’s a shame that all this creative work is now trapped in the wrapper of the rest of the game. Alas.

Pros+ huge potential, great concept
+ easy to read and navigate the UI
+ gorgeous artwork
+ interesting universe
Cons- EA = Early Abandonment
- an unfinished game
- no real end goal
- not enough depth to make it a decent sandbox
- still rather buggy

Help Me Help YouIf you did not find this review helpful, I would really appreciate your constructive criticism - tell me why it wasn’t helpful for you. It’s my hope to make the reviews that I do take the time to write up, as helpful as they possibly can be.

Rothana's Steam Review ArchiveFor those that are interested in seeing more of my reviews, I have set up an archive of them at an external website. I don't earn anything off of this at all, it's just a little side project that I add to when I can. Steam won't let me create a direct link though, so you'll need to make your own way to the URL I describe now: rothana dot weebly dot com

Footnotes
*Any prices that I mention are in CDN because that is what I see.
**I will not be keeping an eye on whether the links are up to date, so if they are broken I apologise. Remember that these are external websites and I'm just trying to be helpful - I'm not responsible for the content on the other end.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Spacebase DF-9 is a fun little rogue-like Dwarf-Fortress-ish game where you build and control a base in space, while fighting off potential invaders. It is a good-looking game filled with potential that is never quite realized and, in the end, it eventually feels very shallow.

It's easy to recommend Spacebase as an amusing little distraction, but not as an in-depth game of strategy or exploration. Unfortunately, it is in a price-range that demands far more of it. I can not recommend this game at or anywhere near its full price of $25 USD. There are numerous similar titles out there that are only a few bucks or even completely free that accomplish far more.

Pretty, but empty.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Spacebase had the potential to be a cool game and I liked the concept. As of this writing (and I don't see myself opening it up again) I have 5.7 hours of gameplay over the course of development; that's about as much gameplay as you can squeeze out of it. Truth be told you can run through about all the game has to offer at this point in one two-hour sit down - and that's fine - but definitely not for $25.00. I think the price tag is what really bugs me and, personally, says a lot about the way the higher-ups at Double Fine truly feel about the whole situation.

Yeah, the whole rush to 1.0 is a bit of a joke and there won't be much to the vanilla full game. But to have the audacity to charge $25.00 in Early Access! And given that the time between now and its 1.0 release is mainly for bug fixing means you're not getting any more bang for your buck in terms of gameplay (i'm not sure a tutorial counts).

This game was gifted to me nearly a year ago and bought by the giver for about the price of a movie ticket. I got nearly 3 movies-worth out of it, so by that reckoning we're doing alright. That being said, I would be incredibly angry to have bought this for $25.00 only to find what the game holds (and more or less will hold at release). It all seems like poor sportsmanship" on Double Fine's part. So your game lacks polish and contains less gameplay than some free Flash games; at least be honest about what it's worth.

In any case
hoursPlayed: likely drive the price to where it should be...somewhere around $5."

reviewText:
Product received for free

SDF9 is not very amazing at all. In the past I've held Double Fine in somewhat of a high regard, but this game just isn't very good at all, for a multitude of reasons.

Namely, it is unfinished. It is abandonware. And yet DF have the gall to keep selling it. On top of this, there are people making mods in order to fix the game. This should not be necessary, and sends red flags from the get go.

Playing some of the game you immediately see that it has a very unfinished feel:

The controls are rather clunky, and there are quite a few problems with the graphics. I can't find out how to rotate the display, which means [as it's in an isometric view], lots of stuff are hidden and can't be easily accessed. Many of the elements end up 'overlaying' themselves on each other, evidence of problems in the graphics engine itself.

The gameplay is rather boring, frankly, and the game lacks flow. You're just dropped in without any real explanation of what the point is. Every now an then a passer by might interact with you with some, well, 'odd' dialogue is probably the nicest way to put it.

The sound design in this game is probably the best part, honestly. It has some nice background music.

Just to TL;DR, Don't buy it, its a shambles.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DF9 was a disaster waiting to happen. And now it has done just that.

I was surprised by how polished" this game looked back when I first played it in one of the first alphas. The graphics and animations looked a lot more "expensive" than in similar games (mostly because they seem to be using 3D for everything while other games just use simple 2D sprites often with barely any animation)
date: even the UI felt a bit overengineered.\n\nAt the same time the releases rarely addressed game-breaking bugs (e.g. airlocks being death traps) and frequently added seemingly arbitrary features that didn't really improve the gameplay other than giving players more bugs to worry about. I guess the project could be described as ambitious
recommended: but then again the same would be true for games like Prison Architect and Rimworld
hoursPlayed: both of which have been able to maintain some level of consistent narrative over a large number of releases (without needing to re-release every single version several times to provide hotfixes).\n\nSome reviewers have said DF made the mistake of treating a supposedly indie
voteText: crowd-funded project as if it were another big team big publisher triple-A title. I don't think anyone but the DF9 team can answer that
helpfulPercent: but it seems telling that a game that was already funded with half a million dollars within the first weeks of the open alpha and that was intended to be entirely financed by pre-release purchases/"backers" has managed to drain its entire budget within only six major releases. If the game needs more than this kind of cash just to make it to 1.0-as-intended
votesHelpful: maybe DF shouldn't have attempted to follow through with this idea. If you're burning money
votesTotal: either find a potent investor who doesn't care
votesFunny: or cut down your development costs to a level where you can bootstrap the project without making f-you money.\n\nTo quote Robot Unicorn Attack: "Your dreams did not come true.""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game will never-ever be worth the full price now that DF have announced that they're abandoning development. It MIGHT be worth a quater of the price IF the community gets into modding it to fix serious issues and add much needed content.

MIGHT
IF


---
I guess i should update this review now that the game has been released and has been updated to 1.05.

I still play this game, and at the time of the edit to this review, i've invested about 70 hours into countless new games.

The updates have helped a whole lot, but the game still has some playability issues:
Doctors will often ignore corpses, which leads to bad morale, which leads to violence which leads to drastic crew loss.

Raider events are too randomised, and can often lead to base failure in the very early game, or general drastic crew loss.

The added raider mega-fleet event is a good idea in principal, but is vastly over-powered.

Construction crew often take huge detors to the next block to be built when in space, which can lead to a new base failing, or causing unrecoverable crew loss in the very early game.

Even with my reasonable system spec and the relative simplicity of the game, it tends to lag-out far too much.

Generally; Base failure seems to be down to chance rather than skill.

There are positives, however
There are mods appearing now, which is great. The community is addressing balence issues and adding reaseatch and similar.

Workshop support is still very much missing, sadly.

Overall:
Has the potential to be a reasonable casual game, but really isn't worth the full price at all. Perhaps at a quater the price, it woulnd't be so bad.

reviewText:
This game is fun, and as a space-themed strategy game about building a base in the middle of nowhere.  That part is fine.  What is not fine however, is how the devs abandoned this game part way through development.  Good thing I bought this on a really great sale when it was around the first few versions.  I cannot recommend this game unfortunately, even though I do actually like the game itself.  Wait for a sale if you want to buy it.  Anyway, here are some pros and cons.

Pros:

+ The game is fun, if you are patient.
+ The community for this game is releasing unofficial updates to the game.
+ Can actually present an occasional challenge.

Cons:

-The devs abandoned this at the side of the road like an unwanted child.
- Might be a bit TOO challenging at times
- $9.99 is a bit steep of a tag for a game that was abandoned in alpha.

Summary:  Buy this game if you like space strategy games, and dear god, please don't buy it at full price, wait for a sale.

reviewText: Unfortunately for all the potential depth the concept of a Dwarf Fortress style management game in space has this game gives you a very shallow puddle to play in. Also the puddle is full of dirty street water. And the puddle evaporates after 10 minutes.\n\nThe fun abrudtly halts when you've completed everything the game has to offer after only a couple hours of play. At that time you've constructed every building and have staff working every job to the happiness of your citizens. Your little humanoids run around your base with a dozen different statistics being tracked that you quickly discover are largely completely meaningless. You are attacked by the same copy paste RNG enemies over and over. It is quite frankly boring and extremely unrewarding.

reviewText: Do not buy this game. Although the release is technically 1.06, this is actually a facade to disguise the fact that Double Fine added a tutorial and some bugfixes following the release of Alpha 6D. There was never a beta, so the already content-sparce game was never very well optimized or balanced, which becomes extremely clear after a playthrough or two. The artstyle is very interesting and arguably beautiful, reminding me of wonderful games like Bastion, but a pretty paintjob doesn't mask the unfinished nature of the Spacebae DF-9. If you like the look and concept of this game, a group of settlers colonizing  a scifi environment, I reccomed a look at Rimworld by Tynan Sylvester. It is very similar, but obviously has a lot more work put into it. In the interest of full disclosure, I do not have a financial interest in either of these games. The modders with which Double Fine entrusted the game played it and then realized that Rimworld is a (subjectively) better game, which is why I can not find a single mod for DF-9 and the modding community for Rimworld is thriving. But the music is nice.

reviewText:
A real shame.

This game had some real potential. I love playing it but without finishing the game properly you run into the same issue with every play.

You build, you research, and you run out of things to do. By the time you have researched all functional upgrades your space base is sprawling and you spend your time reassigning all staff to security detail when the multiple raider attacks start happening and then reassigning them back to their positions after the attack.

Eventually you cannot look in all places at all times and questionable" things begin occurring when your not looking in an  aggravating attempt to "fake" difficulty ala' MarioKart.

The game itself is really not much more completed than what I played when I first purchased the Early Access version.
The AI is shoddy
date: the dialogue feels very much like placeholder dialogue
recommended: and there are items to construct that seem to have no real bearing on game play (can anybody tell me what exactly reactors do or why my turrets don't shoot raider ships out of the sky before they board?).\n\nFeels bad to give this game a negative review
hoursPlayed: but it's earned it."

reviewText:
Current alpha build has a ton of broken content that doesn't function correctly. It does run and play but there are so many things that have been left to the player to finish. You will play for a hour and pretty much experience everything the game has to offer. Now realistically you will play for around a few hours only to have to restart multiple times due to bugs / glitches and the normal game mechanics that end your base early.

There is no save, just save and exit. Even on the map selection there is no exit button just alt f4 out. There is a lot of bugs that create in game issues. Controls cannot be rebound. The only thing on map selection that makes a difference is matter density as all events are currently just based off a random event generator and not what you select on map screen.

From alpha 6 straight to 1.0 release. Sloppy, the game is really a shell half full or half empty?
$25 price tag is really not worth it. Wait till it's five bucks. Personally, I will never support Double Fine after they did this with SpaceBase DF 9. Lessons learned I guess.

Edit - 11/22/2014
There is still no save menu. Threat level has been fixed. There has been a ton of work put into bug fixing but this is all. Game is now listed at $20.01 . Wait till it is $5 or $10 on sale or humble bundle. Most the mod work is just tweaking number values and graphic edits. I cannot recommend this at twenty bucks but half or lower sure pick it up.
Edit- 1/14/15 Typo
Edit- 1/27/15
It would seem DF developers are floating around and banning people on their forums for speaking out against them. Censorship of the people it would seem needs to be added to the list of reasons to avoid this company and anyone affiliated with them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access brings the unfortunate risk of being burned and this game is the first one to have burned me badly enough to write a negative review.

First of all, this is practically a demo that absolutely does not capture what makes this genre fun". Generally the interesting thing about base building games is not about how you can create a utopia where nothing goes wrong
date: but how your base will eventually come to its inevitable end.\n\nSpacebase DF-9 fails to spark any continued enjoyment because of how quickly one can create a stable base without having to worry about anything bad ever happening. One playthrough was all it took to figure out all the kinks for the next time
recommended: where it is entirely possible to reach a state where everything simply balances itself out. This can be attributed to the fact that the game has a very short list of features.\n\nThe short list of rooms have an incredibly short list of items one can add to it
hoursPlayed: so constructing a base on the second playthrough provides almost the exact same experience. It is not surprising how shallow this game feels compared to other games from the genre
voteText: even before you are hit by the realization that the learning curve is really just a horizontal line.\n\nThe random events and the citizens "dynamic" behavior do not add a lot of variety
helpfulPercent: which is something that also quickly realized as you build your base. Understanding the patterns of the short list of events the game throws at you does not take a lot of figuring out
votesHelpful: which is not surprising given the fact that you can count these on one hand. To make things even worse
votesTotal: any negative event that can happen is easily preventable with the aforementioned short list of items at your disposal.\n\nThe only challenging element this game presents
votesFunny: is the incredibly stupid AI that is set on destroying itself as early as building the very first airlock for the base. God help them if they are apart of your mining crew and there happens to be two airlocks to your base
commentsCount: because they are more likely to asphyxiate in space than they are picking which one is closer so they do not die.\n\nAgain
column16: all these negative aspects can be attributed due to the fact that this title is feature INCOMPLETE and will probably remain so
column17: unless it builds a decent modding community (which is incredibly unlikely to happen given the current state). The keyword here is short
column18: as in the feature list
column19: the amount of time this game was given development time until its "full" release
column20: and any enjoyment you can get out of it.\n\nI would be lying if I said I had never been so disappointed by a game before
column21: but certainly not with a game that I was so excited to see completed. In the end I
column22: and several other hopefuls lost out on $20-25 on a game that will never be finished. And while they did not lie to us about "silently pulling the plug"
column23: but they certainly lied about delivering us a "complete" game. With them violating my trust
column24: I will never be purchasing another early access title or Double Fine game ever again."

reviewText: Ok, so this is painful for me, but it needs to be said. I got this game in early access, thinking it would be awesome. I didn't just throw money at it, I read everything they wanted to put in, watched a few videos, and then got it to help support the game... and now I don't think I'm going to do early access again.\n\nDF-9 is a basic space station building game that doesn't have any long lasting gameplay. It looks great, it sounds great, it has the base to be great, but as of this review they have stated that Double Fine will not be doing any further updates. That simple statement moves the game from something that can be great to being mediocre at best. If this changes I will take another look at change my review, but as of now, don’t get it, not worth it.

reviewText:
Today I thought I would write a somewhat higher quality review for this game.
Gameplay is utterly horrible. The interface is very clunky and you will be lucky if you actualy do get a base up to specs.
To begin with the game is so full of game killing bugs that 9 out of 11 games I played were ended NOT because of a disaster, but because of  a major game killing bug.  I even had to restart the game 6 times in a row one time just because there was a bug that was killing it shortly after launching..

Moving on we now go to the general aspects of the game itself:

Support 0/10

This game was released in an unfinished state and is abandoned yet sold on here for $20 (at the time of posting)
I can not give a game in this condition or state any kind of rating at all.  Moving on, the devs are not freindly at all and have banned people for expressing their opinions that the game was a piece of vaporware.  You can take a look at the discussion forums for yourself on this and get a good idea of just how much censorship that is going on and make up your own minds on this .

Graphics 5/10

I am really not impressed with the graphics.  They are not impressive at all and were somewhat below average.

Sounds and Music 1/10

This is an area that is bare bones.  Obvioiusly this area of the game also did not get fnished.  What little music and sounds that there are  annoying as it is repetitous.

Gameplay 1/10

I tried. No really I tried and I got 1 decent game out of 30+ hours which yielded  constant frustration from game killing bugs.  So I give gameplay a 1 because it was fun until the game was killed by a bug.

Fun 2/10
What time I did play that was not killed by a game killing bug was fun so I give it a 2 in this area.


Price:  due to the bugs, unfinished state, and unfrinedly devs it is my opinion that this is one game that definitely NOT worth more than a few pennies.

Bugs and Execution:  The interface sucks, the game is full of game crushing bugs.

I hope this review has been helpful to anyone looking for a new game. Feel free to comment.

Overall :  This game is not just an epic failure but truly IS  vaporware.

reviewText:
Is this game finished? I decided to wait until this game came out of early access before playing, but to me it feels like maybe it should still be. I have played a couple hours already and am already running into bugs left and right. Some times my worker get caught in a loop and will pace back and forth and won't build something even though theres a clear path.

There's also features that I find really annoying. Some times your workers just refuse to work, for what seems like no reason at all. A big complaint is when your people running for cover, or running out of oxygen or in any panic state, they will do NOTHING to rectify the situation, no matter how much your order them to. If the situation is dire, they will probably die instead of fixing the problem.

Game is boring and feels unfinished.

reviewText: I would not recomend this game, go play Rimworld instead. I got this game on sale just after a new update, I though, it's about time to check this really cool game out! And 2 weeks later they abandoned the project. Should have known it was a bit too good to be true, a DF-like with this kind of graphics would mean that the developers are really meaning serious business, thats what i thought. My guess is that the choice of artstyle is what both got them an early success but then a faliure because its so much work representing all these little details that a game like Dwarf Fortress has. If you're not in it for the long haul, don't do early access. The way I see early access is that you let people play a game while youre making it, meaning you are invested/committed in finishing it since you're selling it to real people for real money. Failing to deliver on that will ♥♥♥♥ people off and lose you some credibility/trust. Even if you're in early access you shouldnt be relying 100% on that to be able to complete the game if you're selling it for real money.

reviewText:
Very promising idea, however, the game is unfinished. It has so many glitches, that it is bound to break after some time of gameplay.

To be honest: I'm sick an tired of constantly being the alpha- or beta-tester!

The game lacks the very basics. You can only save your game by quitting. If you accidentally click on how to play" or "New Base" you lose everything regardless if you have saved previously or not. You are not even asked "are you sure?" or be warned the your current game will be lost.

In terms of gameplay:
It is quiet unbalanced. Constant attacks don't give you much time to breath if you have not found the right area in the galaxy for building your base.

Sometimes ships dock at your station and there is nothing you can do about it. If these ships happen to have exterior turrets you might as well start from scratch. Because these turret will tear your crew apart and you won't have a chance to disable or even destroy them.

Again. Haven't the developers even played the game? Other players keep having the same problem. There seems to be no answer accoring to the double fine board.

You have to start over several times in the beginning until you have figured out what to do. There is a tutorial
date: but everything it does is presenting you a half finished base. There is nothing that explains the building items
recommended:
what to take care of or the basics of managing the station.

Sometimes some of your citizens just stop doing their duties and telling you they are bored. You send security to a place where pirates tried to break into your ship and they just keep patroling the base. On occation citizens refuse to enter a room and do maintainance... which results in suffocation of all citizens on your station.

So
hoursPlayed: what do you do against those pirates raiding your base? You build some turrets of your own. Then one of your scientists goes mad
voteText:
usually you would stop him and throw him into the brig until he stops acting up... but the turret has a better idea: it shoots him.

Conclusion:
Under no circumstance is this game in a "release"-state! Beta at most. I feel violated as an alpha-tester again by a company which obviously did not even bother to try and play their own f***ing game! It reminds me a lot of the initial problems of X-Rebirth. But this company does not even show effort in fixing these issues."

Early Access Review

Kickstarter taught Double Fine an unfortunate lesson. You don't have to actually finish video games to sell them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Double fine has decided (in their infinite wisdom) that it is acceptable to simply take a 0.6 alpha build, and jump straight to a 1.0 release build and stating that they are ceasing all development on a game that is by no means feature complete, has major bugs and performance issues, as you would expect from an alpha. Simply releasing the source code is not an acceptable remedy for this, they are basically saying they can't be bothered to finish this, so the community should.

No, that is not acceptable. We invest in an early access title to help ensure the project is complete, and all we expect is a game to be developed to the best of the companies abilities. This is obviously just double fine wanting to cut corners and save money by screwing the consumer out of a finished product. Do not buy! Do not support companies that want to screw the consumer out of their hard earned cash.

reviewText:
Bought this expecting a company with a good reputation like Double Fine to deliver a decent game when it was finished. Sadly it never was and what we are left with is a a practically unplayable mess of a game mainly thanks to awful AI and the player having no direct control over their citizens.

Technicians will happily run over dead comrades into a battle zone to fix a door damaged by raiders. A doctor will then happily charge in to recover the technicians dead body. Builders will think it is a good idea to tear down derelicts to recover materials from the inside so when they demolish an external wall they suck themselves out into space and die.

The raiders are equally stupid as claiming a derelict as your own will often lead to them landing a raiding ship on in where they will demolish the airlock doors and the power and air purifiers trapping themselves inside until they suffocate.

Practically unplayable and with no sort of campaign or any sort of end goal to aim for there is no motivation to try and play working around these issues. Avoid.

reviewText:
Oh Looks like my old review was deleted... (like about 4000 others)

Unfinished game, and abandoned! DO NOT BUY.

tl;dr

Many people have called this a scam, and while some might say thats a little harsh, you have to consider that people paid money up front for this in good faith - this game has basically been abandoned in a buggy and unfinished state.

Double fine have also gained further bad reputation with another game (possibly others if you look...?) and despite enjoying one of their games (Costume quest) I'll not be buying any of their other games, if they can't be trusted to complete a game, how can they be trusted with even a simple trust like long term maininence.

This sort of abuse of early access, is all too common, and begining to give steam a less than stella name... a crying shame for all concerned.

I shall not even bother to catalogue the bugs and terrible balance issues (there basically is none - balance that is there are pleny of bugs!) this was a great idea completely destroyed by really really terrible implementation and even worse disrespect for customers...

the core gameplay that is here is lacking, and there are much better
management sims available than this, go play SimCity instead,

The worst thing is, whats here isnt bad, its a fun game ( not £18.99 fun however)
and there clearly was a lot of promise here, but it lacks a cohesive and complete design
a victim of the early access nature of the game, very basic systems were in place here
with no real central mechanics, while it is noticably graphically superior to
the amnesia fortnight prototype, mechanically it is almost just as under developed and
after 18 months of development, a lot of promised features are completely missing.

While I understand Double Fine has a passion and a penchant for making unique and
interesting games, they absolutely shouldnt not start making a game that they cannot
gauruntee to finish. Spacebase DF-9 should have never been greenlit, I love the idea but
the project completely failed, and Double Fine didnt gamble their own money on this, or
even their investors money on this, they gambled OUR money on Spacebase. The game made
its initial investment back pretty quickly, but due to a high price and lack of features
only a small subset of dedicated fans jumped in.

Early Access is supposed to be a tool for devs to make a little extra money before a game is
finished. The game should be planned and financially secure for completion before coming
to Early Access and in spite of it. It absolutely should NOT be the primary form of financial
resource for a game, ESPECIALLY for a professional studio like Double Fine that is located
in a city like San Francisco that has a high cost of living. This game shouldnt even exist
and poor management has cost me and many others about £19 and it has cost Double Fine
my trust and future trade.

Im Sorry JP LeBreton, I really wanted Spacebase DF-9 to succeed, but you gambled
with my trust and now Double Fine has lost it.

reviewText:
Want to watch experienced space fairing adventureres remove thier space-suits to die in a vacuum for no concievable reason? How about repeatedly getting into fist fights with their best buddies over disparate opinions on the subject of foods? Or perhaps you're the type who enjoys how stalwart security agents decide to go completely nanners  while trying to figure out that airlocks also close on derelict space crafts. If these or any other of mindlessly irritating possibilites make you shiver with joy to think of then this is your game!

*Litter your station with thousands of pointless clutter objects that your crew will leave effing everywhere!
*Marvel at stupid AI which seems to go out of its way to ♥♥♥♥ you off!
*Wonder at clunky building mechanics and counter-intuitive controls!
*Grow food that your bartenders will fill every table with, which your crew inturn will ignore completely while they starve!
*Capture Raiders (or even your own CREW!) who will occasionally just walk right out of thier cells and go totally bonkers!
*Try not to snap your keyboard in two as your crew inexplicably opens the airlock, asphyxiating the entire station!

These and thousands more mind-numbingly stupid bugs (which will never be fixed in this dead game) await you in... SPACEBASE DF-9*ninenine*

reviewText:
I can't say anything that hasn't already been said. It's kind of obvious why I can't recommend this!

* Updating my review as this game is out of Early Access now *

In the good old days of games, companies would invest money into developing a game. Sometimes these investments wouldn't pay off and the game would be unceremoniously cancelled. Remember Snake Plissken's First Escape for the PS2? Me neither. How about the next MMO from Blizzard that was recently canned?

With Spacebase, not only do you get the experience of a game cancelled in mid-development but you also get the luxury of paying for it.

Without chasing the rabbit about the dubious nature of the way this game was funded, it's fair to say that I and everyone else who bought this in early access took a risk that didn't pay off. That doesn't mean I can't and shouldn't have expected better from an established development studio.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If it wasnt for bad optimization on the Pathfinding and other core parts of the game, you would be through with it in aprox. 10 hours max. Comparing the current price (~20 €-ish) with what you would pay for an Alien Isolation key and the tense action and story telling, well lets just say go for A:I.

To make this review more helpful, I will shortly tell you what is currently in the game:
Build a base with oxygen-generators, a simple airlock and some rooms. Create a food source. Mine Asteroids around you and enlarge your base. Upgrade food source and build living and recreation areas. Research stuff.
This, all the while you are defending against Pirate raids, that wouldnt be a problem, if not for the bad Pathfinding and AI in general, that paralyzes your security officer on duty, unable to shoot at the invaders.

PLEASE dont buy this game as it is Vaporware and clearly was ment to be a cash scam all along. Though I see little hope, I will try my luck with a refund for my money, as many people here have been scammed into this product. If you dont believe, just watch the forums here.

Thanks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DO NOT BUY.

Investment in an Early Access game may carry some measure of risk, sure. But from an established studio like Double Fine, there's a reasonable expectation of not only a certain level of quality, but of a completed product. With Spacebase DF9, we're getting neither of those.

Deciding that pre-release sales aren't up to their expectations, Double Fine has opted to cancel further development of DF9, label the next version 1.0, and abandon it. Sure, we'll get some bug fixes in 1.0, but the game isn't nearly ready for release. Between miners who refuse to stop working and suffocate before reaching the airlock, doctors who can't be bothered to retrieve dead bodies, construction items that builders ignore, and a notable lack of features and variety, DF9 is an incomplete and sometimes outright broken product. That never bothered me much because I kept telling myself, It's still alpha. It'll get better."

That Double Fine is using sales of an alpha to determine the game isn't promising enough to finish is astonishing. The lack of commitment to invested fans is even more so. Of course it's not selling well; it's not a good product yet. This almost makes one miss the old days
date: when games didn't sell at all before release. Then no one could complain
recommended: "it didn't sell well enough before we finished it."\n\nThis is the kind of thing we've come to expect from no-name
hoursPlayed: fly-by-night indie devs
voteText: but from a studio like Double Fine it's all the more shocking
helpfulPercent: if not more shameful.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since everyone's reviews are solely their views on Double Fine's recent announcement, I'll go ahead and take a look at the game in its current state.

As it is right now, Spacebase DF-9 shouldn't be called anywhere near completed.  I mean, the game works and all but there are a lot of glaring problems with it.  After a few runs through the game, I couldn't help but notice that every space sector you play in has almost zero differences between them.  The astro density determines how much asteroid is in your area to mine from, which is appreciated, but it hardly makes up for everything else.  The threat level has very little difference, as it apparently suggests how often your base gets showered on by meteors and debris, while warpgate proximity indicates how often you get potential new residents passing by.  What is evidently missing is where Raider occurrences would be placed, since they happen fairly regularly.

The Raiders themselves are stupendously overpowered.  The raiding parties vary between one and three Raiders that *will* decimate your population, no matter how well-trained your Security staff is.  The reason for this is because they tank damage like it's nothing while killing a majority (if not all) of your residents in less than five shots each.  The defensive turrets don't offer much by way of defense.  As the camera is locked to only one perspective, you only have the option to face the turrets downward (i.e. towards the bottom of the map) to either the left or right directions.  Seriously, you can't really use them to shoot at the approaching vessels since they have to be *inside* the base.

The base amenities are also a joke as follows:
- Despite having oxygen capacity for X number of people, the second I fill the base to capacity, the oxygen recyclers eventually fail as if I was overbooked (despite each recycler to be working perfectly at roughly 80-85% durability).  This caused my residents to panic and run around, abandoning all jobs and waiting until they either starved to death (because they used up all of the matter in stock) or waited until the next Raider party exterminated them all.
- The bar doesn't offer much, since it's the only thing that works in the Pub zone.  I have seen neither the fridge nor stove used at all so they're essentially useless.
- I set up a Reserch Zone and set a tech to research but my Scientist was busy doing everything else while on duty rather than actually research anything.


Overall, the game pretty much sucks since each playthrough is just the same thing: see how big your base can get before Raiders kill them all.  And given how Double Fine's treating the game now, I'd have to agree with everyone else.  The developers are basically dropping the project and turning the rest of the game's development over to the community after announcing that they're releasing the source code for the scripts and pushing the game out the door with a 1.0 full release version.  Avoid this game and pick up somthing better instead, like the classic StarTopia or even Prison Architect (which I also have). Spacebase DF-9 is simply a waste of time and money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A cute little game that had potential to be good. It was basically a small space colony simulator. I'd say it does have potential for some hours of play, but once you've made a well functioning base there's nothing else to do really.

The game has bugs and gameplay issues and has recently been abandoned by the developers; shoved out the nest unable to properly fly. At best the development company is incompetent with time and money, and at the worst they are liars and thieves. Possibly both.

Right now it's $24.99 on Steam. Is it worth the money? Not in the least. Go download Dwarf Fortress for free and you'll be much happier.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If it wasnt for bad optimization on the Pathfinding and other core parts of the game, you would be through with it in aprox. 10 hours max. Comparing the current price (~20 €-ish) with what you would pay for an Alien Isolation key and the tense action and story telling, well lets just say go for A:I.

To make this review more helpful, I will shortly tell you what is currently in the game:
Build a base with oxygen-generators, a simple airlock and some rooms. Create a food source. Mine Asteroids around you and enlarge your base. Upgrade food source and build living and recreation areas. Research stuff.
This, all the while you are defending against Pirate raids, that wouldnt be a problem, if not for the bad Pathfinding and AI in general, that paralyzes your security officer on duty, unable to shoot at the invaders.

PLEASE dont buy this game as it is Vaporware and clearly was ment to be a cash scam all along. Though I see little hope, I will try my luck with a refund for my money, as many people here have been scammed into this product. If you dont believe, just watch the forums here.

Thanks

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I hate writing such short reviews but I simply wish to express my opinion after many hours of gameplay (I do get to give a post 36 hour review, regardless):


Post 18 hour review summary (terminated as of release information until 1.0): I would STRONGLY recommend not purchasing this project until you see what comes in at 1.0 release. The ship has sailed, so to speak, on spacebase DF-9. The money brought in for DF-9 was considered insufficient to continue the project and the developers are going to ship the product as is.  You are welcome to receive a product that, with slight and fully justified speculation, will remain permanently as an alpha (it never reached beta) in support of double fine but I would be cautious.


I do recommend to all early access payers, however, to recognize how frequently we receive products that are not even identified as alpha or beta" and to be kind to double fine. I would suggest most players refer to many battlefield and call of duty releases to see how beta's can be pushed out as "final projects". Double fine has to begin to regain some form of capital from this project and the only way they can is by releasing the game. I commend the team for being open and honest about their decision
date:
as hard as it is.

+ Double Fine was open and honest
+ Graphics are well managed
+ Concept well thought out and fun
+ Obvious love and commitment put into the project

Negative

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is completely unfinished and is going into full release without being even close to completion, which is just an attempt to squeeze some money out of an abandoned game.
They also promoted the game on Steam to try and lure people to buy it just before they dumped all the promised features and abandoned development, which in my eyes is sneaky and deceptive and best, and borderline criminal at worst.
After trying repeatedly to start building the base. Just *start* the base that is, I encountered a series of bugs and issues which meant that my crew didn't go into the base I had built, died for no real reason etc etc. There is no guidance to indicate what is wrong, so it is hard to tell when it is a bug or you have made a mistake. The answer is probably both.
Avoid avoid avoid.

reviewText:
I started with DF-9 very early on, the updates were consistent and beefy enough that it kept my attention and I didn't feel I wasted too much time with a few new stations every build.

New problems would of course pop up every Alpha release, but that is to be expected and for the most party they were ignored, yet underlying and game breaking issues never seemed to get fixed that made the end game for the most part pointless while cosmetic and uneeded areas were implemented.

The game is playable for the most part but feels to have been abandoned after being pushed into release after it seems it ran out of money. I would have even recomended the game had the Devs fixed what is there, I could have forgiven the game missing many of the promised features but as it stands now until it gets some much needed attention the review is going to remain negative and I can't in good faith recommend it to anyone which really is disappointing as it had such promise and I did enjoy it despite being broken and unplayable past certain points.

reviewText:
Perhaps some should tell Double Fine a Tutorial stage is supposed to be easy?
The Tutorial stage is actually quite difficult for a newcomer - the 'area' the tutorial station is placed in has a 'high threat' level, and any time I tried to expand my station by adding a new feature, I found myself swarmed with raiders so that any residents I had out in space suits were inevitably killed. I cannot count the number of times my space station found istelf down to a tiny crew due to the rest being killed off. You will have much more satisfaction with the 'New Base' option.

This is a game with  basis, but too many frustrating points. What would help:

- the ability to 'jump' to a location on the map when a message is given, ie, a derelict has appeared, so-and-so is under attack, etc

- the ability to 'jump' to a resident from the roster

- a clearer indication of residents' moods and wants

- more options for decor/entertainment

- a help menu that lists the different features and what they do, instead of a too-difficult tutorial

- more features!!!!

On the whole, I know I will keep playing for the construction aspect, which is why I bought it, but I cannot honestly recommend it to anyone yet. Perhaps Double Fine will come back to it at some point; in light of the negative reviews it's getting, though, I rather doubt it.

reviewText:
Review for version 1.01

Its ♥♥♥♥in horrible. Still buggy as hell. Still very little to do. The goals are pointless and more like achievements (get 50 people, kill 50 raiders, build every object).

My 45 minute experience on the new 'release' included such highlights as:

My best tech sufficating because they were outside shooting at nothing, and nothing that I did stopped them (changed role, cuff, send to infirm/brig)

The 'holdables' littering that map from the countless people that just 'died' for bugger all reason.

A part of my station catching fire, and 5 people dying because I locked the room down and opened it to space to clear the O2. What did everyone do? Jump in their suits and go around through the open door, start fighting the fire AND THEN GET OUT OF THEIR SUITS IN A ROOM WITH NO O2.

Fire animation remains after the fire is extingished. Now my base has a bunch of camp fires around it.

In a area with 'Very Low' raiders, had 10 raids between new colonists (not including the potental raids in the form of message that I know the answer to to make them not raid)

Colonists are still stupidly difficult to please. I have to click through 3 or 4 menus to figure out whats wrong with them.

Construction workers die pulling down a wreak because it had a alien in it. The alien attacked and killed a construction worker (who, I would like to point out I cant control to make him run away) dispite that fact that the 'room' the alien was in was open to space along the entire lenght of it. About 15 squares open to space. After killing my construction worker the alien ran FURTHER into the room, and only then was sucked into space.

Raiders still use the airlock, which means to beat them: wait until the raiders desuit in airlock > pause > unzone room > lock door to base > open door to space > they get sucked out. There is no reason at all to ever fight these raiders. This is the single best way to beat them. And it sucks.

Honestly Ive got like 100 more gripes just from the last 45 minutes I've been playing the new update, but I can sum it all up with:

Game sucks. Feel half finished (because it is). Wish I didnt buy it. Dont buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In this game you essenitally layout rooms on a 2d grid made to look like space.  People randomly come up and ask to join your station where you have to keep them alive and happy and also use them to help keep your station running.  Sometimes you get invaders.  The core features to make it a base-building game are there.

While the developers had some good ideas, they did not get fleshed out nearly enough and there is very little content otherwise.

With the announcement of release just a month or two away it's clear that the developer abandoned this title well before it was able to reach it's potential.   Fun for a couple hours but not worth the $25 asking price.  If you can grab it for 5 bucks or less it may be worth it.

reviewText:
I've logged a lot of time into this game, and pick it up every now and then and play it for stretches at a time. You'd THINK that would lead me to recommend it, but no. I don't recommend this game to purchase.

I started playing the prototype that released with the Double Fine prototype bundle, and I really, really enjoyed it. I was so thrilled when the game hit Steam, and couldn't wait to see where it went. Well, it did add features to the prototype game, which I was playing regularly, so in that sense I'm still enjoying it. However, the game is extremely unfinished and buggy. Asking $10 for it is a slap in the face to consumers; they should ask no more than $1 or so for an unfinished game, if that. Basically, I've played more completed games from Pyweek, and that's folks slapping together games in a week -_-

All that said, I do like playing this game; I enjoy the space sim aspect, and since I've never really gotten a successful, self-maintaining base running it's sort of a perpetual challenge. But I can't recommend it to others because it's so broken. I'm surprised Double Fine has the balls to keep it in the Steam store at $10.

reviewText:
Being a fan of the old “Tycoon” games and “Theme Hospital” I was really excited about Space Base DF-9. I thought for sure reviewers were being too hard on it, so as soon as I saw it pop up in a Humble Bundle I was ecstatic… But, all of my excitement was for naught. Almost 6 hours wasted and I can pretty well guarantee I will never touch this title again.

TL;DR
There is a ton of promise here. When the game is running smooth there’s not a lot to complain about (except maybe lack of construction options), but eventually that smooth ride will be over and you’ll realize nothing works like it should, if at all. So while playable you’ll hit a point where the effort to advance isn’t worth it. If you still think you want to punish yourself by playing this game make sure you check out http://www.spacebasehub.net/ for the unofficial patch, the mechanics are still broken but everything else has been improved.

In-depth Review
Overall Gameplay:
The basic construction and management section of the game is fairly well done. It’s very similar to “Theme Hospital”, but with a slightly improved interface. That’s where the positives end. So many things are broken that it becomes unnecessarily difficult, and not in a fun, challenging way but in a “oh there’s another thing that doesn’t work right” kind of way.
Here are just a few examples of things you’ll see characters do:
- Die of suffocation despite being surrounded by rooms with oxygen and having access to an airlock with space suits,
- Become incapacitated (not dead, just lying around uselessly) indefinitely. If they’re Raiders they actually might be back up and start killing people!
- Be marked for the brig or infirmary but never go there
- Scientists not researching (despite being assigned research and having a research station).
- Ignore the 3 fire extinguishers near the fire, and instead stomp on it until they catch on fire, then run around the base being ignored by everyone else until they burn to death… Actually that might’ve been the most entertaining part of the game!

Presentation:
The user interface is easy to navigate but overly simple. You only have 1 save slot and the game auto saves by default, so if you’re not careful it’s quite easy to erase a save game by clicking on the wrong thing and not exiting before it overwrites your game.

The graphics are fine. They’re quite obviously a throwback to “Theme Hospital” (how many times can I name dop?). It works well for the genre, and they’re fairly sharp.

The sound is outright boring, the music is nothing impressive and off the top of my head I honestly don’t remember any sounds other than that and the chirping alarm if you zoom in far enough.


Summary:
This game could be so good, but as in so many cases now it looks like the developer took their money and ran. In my love/hate relationship with Early Access this is why the hate portion exists. I’d give it a 3/10, it’s playable and as long as things work right it’s quite enjoyable, but the unpredictable and frustrating broken mechanics make it another EA Trash title. Pick it up in a bundle with some good games or for $1 or less and get a couple hours of fun… But DO NOT, under any circumstances pay any more for it than that. Especially when you could get the vastly superior Theme Hospital and forget this all together.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is in ALPHA. You should expect bugs.
If you are surprised by the fact that there are bugs, I honestly don't know how you're breathing right now.

Spacebase DF-9 is an excellent concept for a game. It's like a space-themed Prison Architect: you micro-manage the needs of your crew, build/destroy sections, new world events happen, etc.

But that concept has been poorly executed. The updates seem to be coming fewer and farther between, with not much added to keep your interest. It seems Double Fine have put this game on the back burner.

And as I said, it contains bugs. The AI of characters is still a bit dumb, but it has improved since I started playing.

All in all, if you're very patient, and don't mind waiting around for updates and waiting for the game to figure out what you want, it has potential. Whether that potential is worth 25 USD is a personal choice.

reviewText:
Spacebase DF-9 feels like it had so much potential, but very quickly demonstrates that it has failed to achieve it...

I am honestly yet to be able to experience it's full potential as multiple times now, before even getting established, and with a only a handful of people on board, I've been raided in a 'low' threat zone and leaving me to chase my tail, hoping for new residents to come along to replace my losses... This makes even getting your spacebase established, with a reasonable population, an arduous and frustrating task...

Limited resources are just that, limited, even in areas with alot of asteroids to mine, you will find that they are depleted quickly and constructing large bases (like those shown in the screenshots) seems improbable...

If you're a sucker for punishment, and can pick this up on special, Spacebase DF-9 is probably something you'd enjoy, otherwise, this is not for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Unfortunately the final release of this game is not an improvement on the earliest alpha at all. Throughout the alpha the gameplay did not change at all. Instead each alpha update added some tacked on crap that contributed very little to the game.

Good
The characters you construct a base for seem to have depth. They have feelings and thoughts and you can read about them and so on. The basic gameplay elements for a base builder are there and function.

Bad
The game seems to be caught somewhere between Dungeon Keeper and the Sims. Unfortunately, the emphasis seems to be on Sims gameplay. The station inhabitants have clearly had more effort put into them than the actual gameplay. This could have been a positive thing, as it is in the Sims which is a great game, except without a base and proper neccessities all your inhabitants will die. So you find yourself in a panic to build a base early, made all the harder by the fact that your workers spend more time socializing and posting to their spacebook" than building things essential to survival. This is made even more frustrating by the single most terrible UI I've seen in a modern game ever.

In conclusion
date: the game isn't finished. The gameplay in Spacebase is incredibly underdeveloped and clunky. There isn't even anything to do. You build a small base and then there's nothing. You could make a bigger base
recommended: but there's no reason to. There's no challenge. Despite a year and a half of development this still plays like a terrible demo."

reviewText:
Bought this on the starting day of Early Access, was so excited for the game. Played for hours until the broken features rendered efforts moot.
Planned updates were few and far between, and I kept hope that down the road the finished product would be better.
Then the cut=and=burn announcement came from DoubleFine- they'd completely misunderstood the Early Access model and were dumping this game essentially 'as is' and hoping the community of people that were originally excited about it will fix their game for them.

On 1.0 release day, I find I now have a gift copy of SpaceBase DF-9 *and* Hack-n-Slash, another of their games I wasn't interested in, as if this solves their failed problem. Pay for the promise of one good game, get two crappy ones instead?
No Thanks.
This isn't the first time Double Fine has played me for a fool as a customer, but it will be the last.

reviewText:
As a long time fan of Double Fine it hurts me to say that you all should be ashamed of yourself.

Not because you betrayed your word, which you did. Not because you essentially scammed loyal fans out of money, which you did. Not because the game is incomplete, which it is. Not because you botched the project at the expense of your fans, which you did.

You should be ashamed because you have hurt the entire industries trust and faith in early access, small developers, and where to trust developers.

I understand not all early access projects work out, I understand that buying into early access is a risk. This however was pure deception on behalf of the developers.

You don't deserve to be distributed on Steam and you don't deserve my money ever again. Shame on you Double Fine you lost a fan, a supporter and revenue.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is buggy and the gameplay is weak. I bought it as Early Access to support the developers, but they've just announced that they're going to fix up what bugs remain (which is a lot) and just ship it as version 1.0... then never update it again.

There are base management mechanics in place, but there is no interplay: everything kinda operates as a stand-alone system, so there's very little to do but boring mechanical tasks. You'll run out of content in about 5 hours. The AI is awful: the last time I played (a week ago? 2?) I lost 10 people because they all crowded into a tiny outpost away from my main base and suffocated to death instead of just leaving through the airlock.

It was a mining outpost. There was nothing in there but an incinerator. There was no reason to go there, and even less to stay, but...

Well, that's Spacebase DF-9 in a nutshell. There's no reason for anything.

It's not worth the current price, $24.99. If you can get it for a fiver, then it's probably worth that.

Or hey, maybe I'm wrong and a Christmas Miracle will happen and this game will suddenly become amazing when it hits 1.0.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game works but is prone to odd glitches like losing oxygen or bad AI for the citizens inhabiting your station. Once you've built everything there is nothing left to do as there are no objectives, its a sand box. It could be better with updates but since the developer is pulling the plug on that, there won't be any more updates. AI doesn't act in a reasonable way and a small group of two or three raiders can wipe out your crew of 50+ guys due to a lack of just being able to effect  AI  citizens to react. It's just not finished, half baked is more appropriate. It looks good, had potential but inside its still a nasty surprise to find out it's not cooked all the way through.

Production chains are a 1, 2 step process with no real meaningful payoff. Items may or may not build/demolish and random derelect" spawns clutter up space with unusable nonsense as "salvaging" them is a chore. If there are bugs
date: the development team is leaving and won't be around to fix them. As a final product this thing is only something an enthusiast of the genre looking specifically for a space station to run would like. Even then
recommended: there are better complete games available that will fill that desire. At best this game is average but will likely let you down.\n\nDevelopers don't do this for the money
hoursPlayed: they don't get the lions share of it
voteText: the investors do. They do it out of a passion and love to create games. Ultimately looking for that big break that garners them adoration and accolades. They won't be getting that here. Unleashing this deformed beast onto the world is a disservice to customers and a cross that will haunt the programmers for years to come unless they really are just the shills forums claim them to be.\n\nDo not buy unless you want to take a big risk."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This could have been a fun an interesting game if there was anything to do with your base after the first hour or so. Instead, you will just run out of material to mine and slowly watch your base die.

Or quickly, depending on the raiders.

Unfortunatly, the developers rather surprisingly have seemed to have just given up completely on the game, rushing it to version 1.0 even though there isn't even a reasonable end game experiance. If they actually added everything they were planning, it might have been interesting. However, as is, it's simply not worth the surprisingly high cost. While the gameplay that is there is fairly strong and enjoyable to play, there's simply not enough for $25, and it looks like there never will be.

Long story short, avoid this game at its current price. If you see it on a massive (like, selling for less than $5) sale, maybe try it, but honestly, there's really not much here, and certainly very little replayability. If you want a base building game but aren't neckbearded enough for Dwarf Fortress, try out Gnomoria instead. It controls like a potatoe and is pretty hard to get into, but there's also a lot more gameplay to be had, and for a third the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not worth the money.

The game started nearly unplayable. The menu system is hard to use, the citizens would run to their own death, it was impossible to keep things repaired, and there was little to do except wait for the inevitable collapse. Too many people in a room? The oxygen drops low and they become unable to leave the room because the game doesn't distinguish pressure from oxygen. Some of the issues were fixed; most were not.
Going in, I expected many more features by this point, and for development to continue for at least three years. The game simply did not deliver. Instead of fixing core design issues (like oxygen/pressure not being split, inability to respond to crises, and terrible AI), the developers just added on a few features (like asteroids, which quite simply make the game more annoying) and fixed the easy flaws (like technicians doing lots of damage, flying off to repair derelicts, and taking too long to train).

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. I saw it featured very early on and picked it up. It was ok, there was a decent core game, but there were some bugs/glitches etc.

This was when the developers were updating the game.

Since that time, there have been very few, limiting updates. To my mind, there is no real point to the game. The whole thing about choosing where to have your base is very cool, but in reality there is little to no difference. There are lots of rooms you can put down, which is great, but I can find nothing to do apart from put all the rooms down and defend myself against the waves of baddies.
Which leads us onto another problem: Combat
If I was to be nice, I would say that the combat was... flawed. The truth of the matter is that even when you assign people to security, and give them a place the have to defend, if they are talking or playing a game or eating etc, they will simply ignore you while the baddies are quite happily blowing the c*** out of your base.

There are many bugs with game, including the priorities problem as outlined above. This was ok when the game was in development, but now that the developers seems to have abandoned it, there are too many for it to be considered a full game.

That basically sums up my review. It had promise, but there is not enough actual game or polish for it to be considered a complete game. Save some money, go and buy Prison Architect or donate to/download Dwarf Fortress.

reviewText:
Lets leave aside the fact that the game isn't finished, shall we? Double fine decided its done, so lets look at this as a finished product

Spacebase DF-9 is The Sims, but in space. I know what youre thinking, I was hyped too. You can assign different jobs to different citizens and theyll like it a certain amount. Your citizens will scurry around and converse with each other about inane things like space mudcrabs. You can select asteroids to be mined, which works kinda. You can get other people to come by and ask to join your space-hovel, and supposedly they might even try to do other things, but that never happened in my playthrough. You can send you citizens to go and explore derelict ships, and they will find things. You can build rooms, and put things in those rooms, and your citizen will use them. You can give those rooms different named functions, and your citizen will use them for those functions. Spacebase DF-9 is The Sims, but in space.

Pros:

-Aesthetic: If you can count on Double Fine for anything, its that their stuff always looks good. The semi-retro looks of the interface and the hand drawn aliens look nice and stylized. Sending your citizens off to investigate a derelict ship is always a harrowing affair, as the ship is completely dark, with red warning lights flashing ominously through the hallways. Even if you have no idea whats coming, the atmosphere of the ship makes you anticipate losing a few citizens. One fult is that the play space looks very flat, even though your citizens, while in space suits, can go under your space-hovel, which was very confusing the first few times.

-Sound: The soundtrack is short but nice. Ambient trance music has a soft spot in my ear canal, but I found the music very nice, even though it will be seen as repetitive to some. If you dont like, it, you can always mute it and play Eminem, or what have you.

-Core gameplay: The game mechanics I described above are very good, and makes the base of a great sim game. I'll elaborate more on this in the negatives.

-Fun alien designs: I like the designs of the aliens. I didnt see two aliens who looked exactly alike in my playthrough, besides the two humans I started with. Reminds me of Star Wars!

Negatives:

-It isn't Psychonauts. Lets all face facts, the main reason we all buy Double Fine games is in hopes of another wacky, fun game like Psychonauts. It doesnt need to be a Psychonauts game, it just needs to have the same spirit (Although, I'm still holding out hope that if I keep buying DF games, they'll eventually make Psychonauts 2). The plain fact of the matter is that this has none of that spirit. Spacebase DF-9 is as sterile a gaming experience as there is to be found. The most funny thing I did was purposefully suffocate my citizens in the bar. Forshame, Double Fine.

-The gameplay is completely flat. As in grossly, sadly, boringly flat. If you have played 30 minutes of DF-9, you have played 30 hours of DF-9. With the exeption of the rare derlict ships, I spent most of my game watching netflix on the other monitor. Even the derelict ships suck in a way, since even with their mystery, it takes too much time and resource to explore and kill the monsters inside for it to be worth it, since all your citizens will be terrible at fighting. In other games, like the Sims 4, this could be remedied with patches and DLC, but Double Fine has no intention to patch or make DLC for this game, and so were tuck with the husk of a potentially great game.

Ending score: 4/10. A passable game that works just fine but because of its pedigree should be a while lot better than it is. If you really need your fix of a Space Station simulation game, try Space Colony on GOG, if you need a Sims-esque game, just go back to the Sims. If you want a fun Double Fine game, just play Psychonauts or Brutal Legend again.

reviewText: This game could be so much fun but it needs rebalanced and tweaked a bit.  Raiders attack far too often and are too hard to kill before they decimate your base. reviewText:
While there are still many issues in Spacebase DF-9(such as bugs, outdated graphics, and so on), despite the years of production and work, I understand that this is still an incomplete product. Therefore I am not reviewing this game as a complete product, but rather I am reviewing its creative process. As a building management and construction simulator, Spacebase DF-9 fails the most important criterion in any simulation, uniqueness. Uniqueness is a core aspect in simulation games because it is there in which specialties and creativity come together to make an enjoyable and memorable simulation game. Examples of popular simulation games are Goat Simulator, The Sims, and Train Simulator, which all can be easily identified by each of their unique points. That being said, it is hard to find unique points in Spacebase DF-9. As I am writing this review, in trying to remember things that were unique I find myself fixated more on the bugs than actual gameplay.

Overlooking the bugs, let me break down the gameplay. You build a base, gather resources, and make the base bigger and repeat. You have raiders that attack your base but they don’t present a threat if you properly maintain security. You have asteroid showers that happen every once in a while that start fires and destroy structures such as walls and they need to be patched up. You will get transmissions every once in a while so that people can move in, attack, or attach themselves to the base. The difficulty ramps up as your base becomes larger and more populated; you have to keep track of people’s morale, energy consumption, and security.  That is about it.

As I have stated earlier, it lacks uniqueness. The simulation itself is very basic and there seems to be a large amount of creative work in creating the characters. Unfortunately, the programmers made the characters expandable, having them die very easily and having a lot of them makes the characters feel insignificant and therefore, their uniqueness insignificant. As a simulation, this game will not stand out in sales or reviews unless the creative department decides to do some major reworking. Furthermore if unchanged and published, this game will stand out as one of many examples of morale hazard in pre-release gaming.

Note: As I was about to post this I realized that this game was published a year ago. I could not fathom that a game this unpolished and lacking in content could be deemed complete by anyone who took pride in their work. In the end, it seems that DoubleFine just took everyone’s money and fled.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

The game is very minimalist in the amount of control you actually have while being harsh in terms of  difficulty. Save function is save and quit so you can only have 1 base(lazy IMO) and after you get settled the lack of content is staggering. would not recomend to anyone.
